# [**Vue.js**](http://Vue.js) **Audit Report**

# **Introduction**

## **What is Vue?**

Page: [https://vuejs.org/guide/introduction.html\#what-is-vue](https://vuejs.org/guide/introduction.html#what-is-vue)

**Problem**: The opening paragraph is a bit jargon-heavy. The terms like declarative, component-based, and programming model appear before a beginner even knows what Vue does.

**Solution**: Reword the first paragraph to be more beginner-friendly. Example:

“Vue is a tool that helps you build modern web interfaces quickly. It’s built on top of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, and helps you organize your app using small reusable pieces called components.”

**Problem**: The code example is helpful but lacks a short explanation of what it does before showing the result.

**Solution**: Add a one-liner before the code block:

“Here’s a simple example where Vue updates the text as you click the button.”

![][image1]

**Problem**: The terms like “Declarative Rendering” and “Reactivity” are explained, but there are no links or images to help understand them.

**Solution**: Add small help links or icons next to each word that show a simple explanation when hovered or clicked.

**Problem**: The green *Prerequisites* box says that beginners should already know HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, which might scare them off.

![][image2]

**Solution**: Change the message to be more friendly, like:

“You’ll get more out of Vue if you know some HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, However, you can still look around and learn as you go.”

## **The Progressive Framework**

Page: [https://vuejs.org/guide/introduction.html\#the-progressive-framework](https://vuejs.org/guide/introduction.html#the-progressive-framework)

**Problem**: The list of use cases (SPA, SSR, WebGL, etc.) includes many technical terms without explanation.

**Solution**: Add short explanations or tooltips next to each term. For example:

**SPA (Single-Page Application)**: A website that loads once and updates without refreshing.

**Problem**: The first paragraph talks about “ecosystem” and “incrementally adoptable”. These terms are hard to understand for beginners.

**Solution**: Rephrase using simple words:

“Vue is made in a way that you can start small and add more features as you need them.”

**Problem**: Too much text without visuals or examples makes it harder to stay engaged.

**Solution**: Add a small diagram or image that shows how Vue can be used in different ways (like a small project vs. a full app).

**Problem**: The section says not to worry if things sound difficult, but it doesn’t give examples of easy starting points.

**Solution**: Add a line like:

“You can start by just adding Vue to one small part of your website and grow from there.”

**Problem**: The ending paragraph is a bit too formal and long.

**Solution**: Break it into two smaller paragraphs and use friendly language:

“No matter how you use Vue, whether for a simple page or a full app, the way it works stays the same. That makes it easy to learn once and use anywhere.”

## **Single-File Components**

**Incomplete Explanation**

Page: [https://vuejs.org/guide/introduction.html\#single-file-components](https://vuejs.org/guide/introduction.html#single-file-components)

**Problem**: The section introduces the term *Single-File Component (SFC)* and shows a full code block, but doesn’t clearly explain why this is helpful or better.

**Solution**:Add a short line before the code example like:

“Vue lets you write your HTML, CSS, and JavaScript in one file, this makes things easier to manage and reuse.”

**Beginner Unfriendly**

**Problem**:The last paragraph says it’s the "recommended way," but it doesn’t mention that beginners can still start without this format.

**Solution**: Add a friendly note:

“Don’t worry if this looks complex. You can start with simple Vue code in HTML files before using this advanced setup.”

## **API Styles (Options API vs. Composition API)**

 Page: [https://vuejs.org/guide/introduction.html\#api-styles](https://vuejs.org/guide/introduction.html#api-styles)

**Beginner Unfriendly**

**Problem:**  
 The page introduces Options API and Composition API directly, assuming some familiarity with Vue or component-based frameworks. New developers may feel lost or unsure about which API to start with.

**Solution:**  
 Add a welcoming note before diving into the APIs:

“If you're new to Vue or frontend frameworks, don’t worry. Both API styles are beginner-friendly, and you can start with either. Pick what feels easier to understand.”

**Excessive Jargon**

**Problem:** Terms like “component instance,” “boilerplate,” “reactivity,” and “SFCs” are used without explanation. This makes it harder for non-experts or newcomers to follow the content clearly.

**Solution:**

* Define each term briefly in context. For example:  
   *“Single-File Components (SFCs) let you write HTML, JavaScript, and CSS in one file…”*

* Alternatively, provide links to glossary definitions.

**Too Much Text, Not Enough Structure**

**Problem:** The "Which to Choose?" section contains dense paragraphs that pack multiple ideas together. Readers can lose track of the message or get overwhelmed.

**Solution:** Break long paragraphs into short, scannable blocks. Use subheadings like:

* "Comparing the Two APIs"  
* "Choosing Based on Project Type"  
* "What Beginners Should Know"

**Missing Visual Summary**

**Problem:**  
 The pros and cons of each API style are described in prose only. There’s no quick visual summary for comparison.

**Solution:**  
 Include a simple side-by-side table or infographic:

| Options API | Composition API |
| :---- | :---- |
| Easier for beginners | More flexible for complex logic |
| Familiar for those with OOP background | Encourages logic reuse and modularity |

**Unclear Recommendation**

**Problem:**  
 The current recommendation leans toward Composition API as the “default,” without clearly stating why or when Options API might be better for certain users.

**Solution:**  
 Clarify that both styles are supported, and that Composition API is a better fit for advanced use cases—but Options API is simpler to begin with:

“If you’re building a small app or just learning Vue, the Options API may feel more intuitive. For larger apps or more modular logic, the Composition API offers flexibility.”
